name: NPR
text: Need a quick stress break? We recommend listening to humpback whales singing underwater in Glacier Bay National Park. https://t.co/eQGAUfIIBg

name: NPR
text:
Houston's daily coronavirus case count and hospital admission rates seem to be leveling off after a surge in June, but health officials aren't ready to determine if the data are statistically significant yet.
https://t.co/K37W9IMcJP

name: NPR
text:
Laid-off restaurant workers are the largest category of the newly unemployed in the U.S.

And without a big step, one national group warns, "85% of independent restaurants could close permanently." (@planetmoney)
https://t.co/vI9KNZp7nY

name: NPR
text:
Happening tomorrow at 4 p.m. ET: @JazzNight will premiere a concert with @Joshua_Redman, @bradmehldau, @mcbridesworld & @BrianBlade. 

After the set, they'll participate in a Q&A with @NPRMusic critic @NateChinen. 

Join the conversation: https://t.co/El574HtL07

name: NPR
text:
The FAA is inching closer to re-certifying Boeing's 737 Max, saying it plans to issue a proposed airworthiness directive for the grounded jetliner that will address design changes to fix a flawed flight control system.
https://t.co/IMSGc9nAX7

name: NPR
text:
A Minnesota judge has lifted the gag order in the case against 4 former Minneapolis police officers charged in the killing of George Floyd, following opposition from defendants' attorneys and the press.
https://t.co/Ar5jI1x1tw

name: NPR
text:
Jazz Night In America is premiering a pre-produced concert video with Joshua Redman, Brad Mehldau, @jazznight host Christian McBride and Brian Blade tomorrow at 4:00 p.m. EDT. 

While it plays, fans can engage with the musicians in a live chat.

Details: https://t.co/8mOWSf7CFn https://t.co/TCJ5ND2Z7q

name: NPR
text: Black mayors formally called on governors to repeal orders prohibiting local leaders from implementing strategies that reduce the spread of the coronavirus ‚Äî such as requiring the use of face masks.  https://t.co/gagkMCQKQw

name: NPR
text:
The mayors of 15 U.S. cities are calling on Attorney General William Barr to withdraw federal forces immediately, describing the deployments as "wholly inconsistent with our system of democracy."
https://t.co/pAwoQudURa

name: NPR
text:
A historic drop in rates has millions of homeowners refinancing to save money. 

It's helping home sales ‚Äî but amid a pandemic, it's not helping the broader economy as much as it would in a normal recession.
https://t.co/tUsd9sjfkr

name: NPR
text:
Advocates say thousands of independent clubs across the country are at risk of closing if they don't receive government aid soon. 

"You can't serve live music takeout, so we've had zero revenue since March 11," says a small venue owner.
https://t.co/2QyIFhHlDl

name: NPR
text:
CDC data estimates the number of coronavirus infections is about 10 times higher than the confirmed cases ‚Äî still far below what is required for herd immunity, though it's not yet known if the presence of those antibodies prevents reinfection.
https://t.co/Rasa9lfJM2

name: NPR
text:
The president of Portland's police union says federal agents need to communicate better with local enforcement.

"There needs to be communication and coordination to be able to make sure that we keep protesters safe," Daryl Turner says.  https://t.co/LNTiJgAId8

name: NPR
text:
Where does the preference for thinness really come from? 

Author Sabrina Strings argues the origins of modern day fat phobia can be traced all the way back to slavery ‚Äî and Black people are still dealing with the consequences. https://t.co/r0ap4brJU7

name: NPR
text:
In 2013, Camden, New Jersey, rebuilt the police department from scratch.  

Since then, crime has plummeted ‚Äî but many residents say the numbers aren't telling the whole story. 
https://t.co/858vQQGXq0

name: NPR
text: The Confederate flag became prominent as a symbol of opposition to civil rights. New Englanders flying today it tell @vprnet they're opposed to Black Lives Matter. ‚ÄúIf they‚Äôre gonna go off and try to intimidate me, then I'm gonna intimidate them.‚Äù https://t.co/NxAH5c2J2i

name: NPR
text:
In 1992, Moscow designated a "Fallen Monument Park" to house removed statues, including those of fallen Soviet leaders. Today, it's a part of Gorky Park ‚Äî an urban oasis with shady lawns and cafes.
https://t.co/lbwkvZF2dp

name: NPR
text: In the aftermath of George Floyd‚Äôs death, demands for racial justice in the workplace have spread. Even in suburban strip malls, young, low-paid workers are demanding better treatment -- and consequences for their bosses. @whyynews https://t.co/FwAwJdcoZl

name: NPR
text:
Early data suggests opioid overdoses are rising as the coronavirus pandemic increases isolation, despair, and economic hardship ‚Äî all known risk factors for addiction.
https://t.co/BegjC2vHuV

name: NPR
text:
Humpback whales in Alaska have been swimming in quieter waters during the pandemic, as ship traffic has fallen. 

Scientists say it‚Äôs a once-in-a-lifetime chance to listen to whales without the impact of human noise.
https://t.co/Uijza4HIEZ https://t.co/ycgmEEQciF

name: NPR
text:
A powerful hurricane could uproot tens of thousands of people at a time when coronavirus cases are soaring ‚Äî putting evacuation shelters at risk of becoming infection hot spots.

Public health experts warn the consequences could be grave.
https://t.co/M7uEPlFo8e
